title: Work energy theorem - block on flat rough surface

content.question: A block of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> slides with an initial velocity <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> along a rough surface where the coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the surface is <math alttext="mu" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>μ</mi></mstyle></math>. The box comes to rest after sliding a distance <math alttext="d sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. A new block of unknown mass slides with an initial velocity of <math alttext="2 v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> across a surface where the coefficient of kinetic friction between the new block and the surface is <math alttext="the fraction mu over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>μ</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math>. Which of the following expressions represents the distance the new block slides before coming to rest in terms of <math alttext="d sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="4 d sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>d</mi></mstyle><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="8 d sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>8</mn><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>d</mi></mstyle><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="8 d sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>8</mn><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>d</mi></mstyle><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
